pros: * 401K with 90 day, 100% vested, company match of 100% for 3%, 50% match for additional 3% * 401K offers a Roth and Traditional pre tax plan * ESPP with a 15% discount * Health insurance is cheap but coverage is great * Free & discounted college and educational programs for you and your family * Job security!!!
cons: * Need better O-J-T programs, not leadership training (great programs) but better actual every day grind training that’s relevant to the position you have * As great frontline leadership and field executives leave or retire we are getting more people from outside of our industry or those who get more face time with leadership and they are lacking the operational know how and ability to understand daily challenges, hire from within, get out in the field and have real conversations with those who lead from the front * Frontline employees have received the same pay increase percentages that SG&A line employees have despite working everyday through COVID and being hit with record high inflation * Get better technologies, too many antiquated software programs, internet is terrible at most locations, most software we use doesn’t pull the analytical data required to maximize efficiency nor do they produce data that most key metrics are based on

job_title: Trash Truck Operator in Ambridge, PA
pros:
WM is a multinational corporation. I can only speak about what I've seen at the sites where I worked. 
The wages are a little better than other trash companies in the area, and good benefits.
Also, if life takes you somewhere else it's easy to transfer to another site.
cons:
WM is a multinational corporation. I can only speak about what I've seen at the sites where I worked. 
In the last 10 years I have only experienced a few short periods where the site was fully staffed. Management drives employees away. If fully staffed, and everyone shows, people will be sent home without pay. When short staffed management will move people and trucks around at a whim and require overtime. HR literally said "You are ours for 60 hours a week." and have disciplined employees for not doing more than the routes they signed up for. If you call off sick you may be required to work a Saturday and get points against you for calling off on Saturday.
It would also be nice if you had the time to use the benefits you earn.

review_title: One of the best companies I have worked for

Though lately like every industry, they have been impacted by labor shortage and supply-chain delays as well as high inflationary impacts to cost of doing business
cons: Just like any large corporation, your experience may vary based on your market area leadership. Some are better than others. While there is heavy investment in technology and environmental/recycling projects, some of the in-house operational applications and software are a bit old school and need updating. Understandably it would be a behemoth project to overhaul something like that. Most of the operational-level jobs are male-heavy, though they are trying to recruit more women.

review_title: It's fine, easy work for ok pay.
pros:
The job is relatively easy once you learn all the proprietary systems. The learning curve is the only read hard part. Benefits are solid and probably the best thing, nice 401k matching. Tuition assistance is there too.

As far as career advancement, if you are interested in operations you should be able to get an opportunity there within a few years if you are good at what you're doing.
cons:
Pay structure leaves too much to be desired. 2% base pay raise per year, whether you are the best at what you do or the worst. Low incentive to be amazing. This will leave you lagging behind new people getting hired, as I have recently learned. They will outpace you in pay while being less experienced, and that is objectively bad business.

Also mandatory rotated Saturdays and occasional holidays. Not great for work/life balance when you end up with a 5am Saturday shift that pretty much erases your weekend.

Management try to pretend to have a family feel but it's all smoke and mirrors. Behind closed doors the truth comes out about the shady tactics used to manipulate workers. They come up with ways to make people quit by making their work life suck so they can say they didn't fire them, they manipulate employees to not file workman's comp claims, they have all kinds of schemes to use company resources for personal gain like funneling goods through corrupt venders or purchases of TV's and stuff that they say are broke but really go to their house. They use employees to work on their personal projects like welders building their personal trailers, mechanics working on their personal vehicles, having employees wash their personal vehicles and go to their house and cut their grass on the clock with the company mowers. Just all kinds of shady crap. They use the gas cards and green cards for personal expenses. The level of corruption is staggering. At my site they won't even hire the correct amount of managers because the few they have are in cahoots with each other and they're afraid an outside person would turn them in. They won't hire black people but then claim it's because they don't apply but behind closed doors they tell nonstop racist jokes and make racist comments. You can never get ahold of management either, they don't answer their phones, they're never in the office and when they are in the office it's because they have the mandatory meetings on the computer that last hours and they're unavailable during those times. Even when you do talk to them they hardly ever remember what you said so nothing gets done. They push the safety narrative a lot but in the same breath they tell everyone they're gonna be out of a job if they don't work faster. Even when employees are telling them that working faster is what leads them to make mistakes while driving and makes them unsafe. You're under constant video surveillance. There are cameras inside and outside of the trucks, they hire companies to follow you around doing video surveillance, and the managers follow you around hiding taking secret video. It's all very draconian. Things that they aren't legally allowed to make you do are volun-told. They say they need you to volunteer but if someone ask if they have to they tell you that you don't actually have a choice not to volunteer, hence volun-told.

review_title: Avoid this place if you value your life.
pros: Pay is ok. Paid weekly. Benefits are ok. Job can be fun especially when kids faces light up seeing a garbage truck. You can get a lot of tips come Christmas time if you're a regular route driver. When on route, you're on your own. Management doesn't bother you too much if you're doing the job well.
cons:
Bad Management. Corperate keeps adding safety rules and devices. You can't just go out and be a garbage man anymore.  You have to be much more careful. However, they still expect you to get the same routes done at the same pace. It results in you being overworked and super frustrated. Sometimes the rules aren't the safest way to do something.

They've taken away many things that used to motivate people to be good workers. They used to give safety bonuses. They uses to have raffles for employees with good safety and efficiency and attendance. They used to have performance based raises. Now everyone gets the same raise.

 They reduced vacation. They used to take the average hours you worked and increase your hourly rate on vacation hours so you could use only 40 hours vacation but still get the same pay for the week. Now you have to use more vacation hours to get the same weekly pay. You'll average 60 hours a week at this job. So, you'll have to use 60 hours vacation. 

The reduced the boot reimbursement. It used to be 260 a year. Now it's 185.

Maintenance is a joke. Management in maintenance is real petty too.

There is crazy amounts of turnover. Red Flag. I've been with this company so long that it's scary to change jobs. If I were you, I'd avoid this place.

job_title: Call Center Representative in Windsor, CT
pros: I do not have one single pro for this company
cons:
As a rep you are micro managed to the max. Every second of your day is set for you and completely robotic. There is no space to be human. You get marked down for any “personal time” meaning getting a cup of water or using the restroom….

The pay is not livable and you are required to do so much with such little pay. 

I have only been working here for 4 weeks and I have never been so miserable. I am already interviewing for another job. Might I add, almost all of the other people who were hired with me are also miserable. We have a group chat where we talk about how unsupported and ignored we are by management. 

The supervisors talk about how great this company is and how supportive everyone is and it actually makes me laugh because it is quite literally the exact opposite. 

They have asked us after our training and the start of our nesting period to provide feedback and ask for what we need. We all spoke up about what problems we are facing and they ignored us completely. The clearly can not keep employees because they have pushed us through so fast that we didn’t even get our full training. 

When I tell you don’t waste your mind, I mean it. It is such a waste, so disappointing and one of the most degrading jobs I have worked.

review_title: Lots of turnover- North Phoenix sales call center
pros: Benefits, reputable company, great co-workers, and potential long term career. There are a few caring managers and team leads that genuinely care for their employees.
cons:
Reps and managers are micromanaged beyond belief. Every aspect of your day is controlled by upper management. 

This location is focused on hiring college grads knowing they will only be there for a short while till something better comes along since the automatic metrics will eventually catch up. IF you are liked you will moved to other teams that focus more of an account book than transactional business. 

There are minimum daily metrics you have to meet and will be written up for not meeting those numbers. Once on plan you have to practically do a Hail Mary to get off plan, if you are not liked you might as well update your resume. Ask yourself why are they always posting for sales reps?

Sr Director and Sr Management like to create chaos within the inside managers and team leads to divide and conquer. It also helps keep everyone in check and in line. From what I was told is managers can't even trust each other. 

Again this is only for the call center in North Phoenix, from speaking to other reps on other teams across the company things are much different.

pros: Great company to work for.
cons: No complaints about the company.

pros: Benefits and wage, coworkers are very nice.
cons: Where do I begin. Lets start with the work hours. They claim that you have a set schedule. Unfortunately for their employees, they force you to stay late to complete work that is not part of your job description. Recently, they also went to a mandatory 10 hour schedule. For example, if you start at 9:00 AM your mandatory schedule is until 7:00 PM. Another issue is that corporate forces their employees to work every holiday except for Xmas. A very new policy that Corporate has put into place is to punish employees for calling out on a Monday, or to punish them if they call out on a holiday. For any reason. Did you break your arms in a car accident on the way to work? Your are punished. Suddenly have a family member go to the hospital? You are punished. They claim to be a family oriented company, but they repeatedly refuse to take into consideration what FAMILIES need to do with children for school. Yes, parents can send their kids to after-school care, but if their schedule starts before they can drop their kids off and ends after their kids are supposed to be done with after-school care they just tell you "oh well, you need to figure it out" because of their 10 hour policy.

job_title: Outside Sales Representative in Little Rock, AR
pros:
It’s definitely a team atmosphere. Everyone was supportive rather than hyper-competitive with one another. Trainers, senior reps, and managers were great and always around to help or troubleshoot. 
I’m sure things have changed since WM restructured its sales department, but they offered a good base salary and commission structure. You can make some decent money selling for WM. Also, their training methods for new reps learning about the industry were solid. By the time I was ready to go out on my own, I was very confident, which made it easier to rack up those elusive cold-call-closes. Being based in a smaller market, the large accounts were sparse (or had already been sold by the more tenured reps), so I had to target smaller accounts that didn’t bring in large dollar amounts. That made it hard to close enough to hit monthly goals, especially once the pandemic hit. The sales managers were always understanding and willing to help though, which isn’t always the case for a sales job. That, along with the base salary, made life a little less stressful.
cons:
I suppose the biggest con would be the restructuring of the sales department. It was a major shock and seemed to come out of nowhere. I went from having a job I truly enjoyed to being unemployed in the span of a 5 minute Teams call. That’s upsetting on its own, but during the worst pandemic in a century, it was devastating. We all thought our jobs were secure, and the company had made a point to reiterate that starting in March 2020. We were well taken care of until until we suddenly weren’t. We were given severance packages, which was nice, but it didn’t really help with the hurt of being cut loose without warning by a company for which we were all proud to work. 
Another con - hitting salesforce metrics every month. A HUGE emphasis was placed on this. Of course, it was theoretically done to help reps build their pipelines and succeed, but it never felt that way. It seemed like more of a “everyone make sure to hit your salesforce numbers so corporate won’t be mad at us” type of situation. When the pandemic hit, I guess having good salesforce numbers was the only thing we could hang our hats on since sales slowed so much, but it wasn’t helpful and most likely caused some reps to put less than legit stuff in purely to keep themselves and their managers out of trouble.
